security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and code examples in a markdown file. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access. Purely prompt-based guidance for TypeScript/Node.js development.

content.value_statement: Building TypeScript projects with any type leads to bugs and maintenance issues. This skill provides expert guidance on strict typing, async patterns, and performance best practices for production-ready Node.js applications.
actual_capabilities: Enforce strict TypeScript configuration with full type safety
Guide async/await patterns including parallel execution and error handling
Provide streaming patterns for memory-efficient large data processing
Define error handling patterns with custom error classes and Result types
Structure CLI applications using Commander.js with proper user feedback
Configure testing standards with Vitest including coverage requirements
limitations: Does not execute code or run tests
Does not access external APIs or services
Does not modify project files directly
Provides guidance only, not automated code generation

prompt_templates.title: New Function
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a TypeScript function that fetches user data from a database. Use strict typing, proper error handling, and explicit return types.

prompt_templates.title: Error Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom error class hierarchy for my API with ValidationError and NotFoundError. Show the Result pattern for expected failures.

prompt_templates.title: Performance
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this sequential API call pattern to run in parallel using Promise.all. Show how to handle partial failures.

prompt_templates.title: Project Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my Node.js project for TypeScript strictness compliance. Check tsconfig settings, any usage, return types, and async patterns.

best_practices: Always enable strict mode in tsconfig.json with noUncheckedIndexedAccess and exactOptionalPropertyTypes
Use Promise.all for parallel operations instead of sequential await calls
Implement custom error classes with the AppError base class for consistent error handling
anti_patterns: Never use `any` type - use `unknown` with type guards instead
Avoid loading large files entirely into memory - use streaming patterns
Do not throw errors for expected failures - use Result pattern for recoverable errors

faq.question: Does this skill work with JavaScript projects?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on TypeScript-specific patterns. JavaScript projects can use general Node.js guidance but will not benefit from strict typing recommendations.

faq.question: What TypeScript version is supported?
faq.answer: The skill targets TypeScript 5.x with ES2022+ features and NodeNext module resolution for modern Node.js LTS versions.

faq.question: Can this skill modify my tsconfig.json?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance and code examples. You must manually apply configuration changes to your project files.

faq.question: Is my code data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only reads your prompts and provides guidance. No code is transmitted externally or stored beyond the conversation.

faq.question: Why does the skill forbid `any` type?
faq.answer: The `any` type bypasses TypeScript's type checking, defeating the purpose of using TypeScript. It leads to runtime errors that static analysis could catch.

faq.question: How does this compare to other TypeScript linters?
faq.answer: This skill provides architectural guidance and patterns. Use ESLint and TypeScript's built-in checks for automated enforcement of these practices.
